Dialogue: Yes. He moved to Paris when he was fourteen. He played the King of Siam 4,625 times on the London and Broadway stages. What are you doing?

Speaker: denis
Dialogue: One likes to make an effort. A snifter?

Dialogue: You're dead, Denis.

Dialogue: Ah. Well, if I'm dead... who are you talking to? Shall we dance ?

Dialogue: Gentlemen, the Argentinian Junta - which is a fascist gang - has invaded our sovereign territory. This cannot be tolerated. May I make plain my negotiating position. Speaker: admiral leach
Dialogue: Possible... just, Prime Minister. We can have a Task Force ready to sail in forty-eight hours.

Speaker: margaret
Dialogue: Forty-eight hours?

Speaker: admiral leach
Dialogue: But -

Speaker: margaret
Dialogue: But?

Speaker: admiral leach
Dialogue: We have a very narrow weather window. We can't fight in winter down there. Nobody can. If we are going, we have to go now.

Speaker: margaret
Dialogue: Why were the islands left without any naval protection?

Speaker: john nott
Dialogue: In the last round of Defence cuts we judged the risk of invasion to be small.

Speaker: margaret
Dialogue: Did we?

Speaker: john nott
Dialogue: And if you remember, Prime Minister, you agreed that we should reduce the naval presence in the area to an absolute minimum.

Speaker: howe
Dialogue: Margaret, the cost of sending 28,000 men and a hundred ships twelve thousand miles, almost to Argentina, will be absolutely crippling.

Speaker: margaret
Dialogue: I don't think we should be worrying about money at this point, Geoffrey.

Speaker: geoffrey howe
Dialogue: We can't afford to go to war.

Speaker: mp 1
Dialogue: The U.S. Secretary of State has arrived, Prime Minister.

Speaker: general haig
Dialogue: So you are proposing to go to war over these Islands. They're thousands of miles away, a handful of citizens, politically and economically... insignificant, if you'll excuse me -

Speaker: margaret
Dialogue: Just like Hawaii, I imagine.

Speaker: general haig
Dialogue: I'm sorry?

Speaker: margaret
Dialogue: 1941, when Japan attacked Pearl Harbour. Did America go cap in hand and ask Tojo for a peaceful negotiation of terms? Did she turn her back on her own citizens there because the islands were thousands of miles from mainland United States? No, no, no! We will stand on principle or we shall not stand at all.

Speaker: general haig
Dialogue: But Margaret with all due respect when one has been to war....

Speaker: margaret
Dialogue: With all due respect sir, I have done battle every single day of my life, and many men have underestimated me before. This lot seem bound to do the same but they will rue the day.

Speaker: margaret
Dialogue: Is this ship a threat?

Speaker: admiral fieldhouse
Dialogue: Both of these ships are carrying Exocet missiles, Prime Minister. Just yesterday they launched- then aborted- an attack inside the exclusion zone. There is a risk they could try it again.

Speaker: francis pym
Dialogue: The Belgrano is sailing directly away from the islands. Can it really be regarded as a threat ?

Speaker: admiral fieldhouse
Dialogue: She's been changing course continually. There's a strong possibility that they're attempting a pincer movement on our carrier group.
ADMIRAL FIELDHOUSE  I advise that we engage them: hit the Belgrano as a warning to the others. Send them all back to port.

Speaker: francis pym
Dialogue: It'll play badly internationally. We'll be seen as aggressors.

Speaker: john nott
Dialogue: This will be an escalation, Prime Minister.

Speaker: leach
Dialogue: If there is to be an escalation, it's better that we start it.

Speaker: minister
Dialogue: It is steaming away, Prime Minister.

Speaker: margaret
Dialogue: Sink it.

Speaker: john nott
Dialogue: Prime Minister -

Speaker: margaret
Dialogue: I must write to them.

Speaker: john nott
Dialogue: Prime Minister?

Speaker: margaret
Dialogue: The families. I must write to them...

Speaker: margaret
Dialogue: Foreign Secretary...

Speaker: pym
Dialogue: I've just been briefed by Admiral Fieldhouse.
PYM  He told me bluntly that if the Argentinians are prepared and willing to risk their aircraft, they have enough missiles to cripple most of our fleet.

Speaker: john nott
Dialogue: President Reagan and President Bellaunde of Peru have some new proposals for the peace plan -

Speaker: margaret
Dialogue: The peace plan? There will be no appeasement. This is a war. A war they started and by God, we will finish. Shall I tell you what I'm going to write to every single one of these families, these heartbroken families? I am going to tell them that no British soldier will die in vain for the Falklands.

Speaker: military voice
Dialogue: Lieutenant Colonel Jones. Captain Wood. Captain Dench. Lieutenant Farlaine. Corporal Hardman. Corporal Sullivan. Corporal Briar.

Speaker: radio vo
Dialogue: Shortly after dark last night, our forces executed what our Commander in Chief has called a brilliant surprise night attack.

Speaker: denis
Dialogue: Thatcher, bed.

Speaker: radio
Dialogue: From their new positions, our forces can see large numbers of Argentine soldiers retreating and streaming back into Port Stanley. Our forces are moving forward to exploit their success.

Speaker: margaret
Dialogue: We were faced with an act of unprovoked aggression and we responded as we have responded in times past: with unity, strength and courage, sure in the knowledge that though much is sacrificed, in the end, right will prevail over wrong.

Speaker: denis
Dialogue: GOTCHA! Well that paid off old girl! Your ratings soared! From the most hated Prime Minister of all time to the nation's darling...The world was at your feet, and Britain was back in business!

Speaker: news reader
Dialogue: The Berlin Wall has fallen. The gates have opened! The police are making no attempt to stop people as they go through.

Speaker: margaret
Dialogue: I don't agree in any measure!

Speaker: geoffrey howe
Dialogue: But Prime Minister the question of the European single currency will come up.

Speaker: margaret
Dialogue: I don't think the country is ready for it yet.

Speaker: geoffrey howe
Dialogue: But we cannot bury our heads in the sand...

Speaker: news journalist
Dialogue: - that there must be a change in that style of management. That Mrs Thatcher must listen more, and on occasion, give in.

Speaker: margaret
Dialogue: There it is again! Why not?

Speaker: minister 1
Dialogue: Because -

Speaker: minister 2
Dialogue: Because people... on the whole... think that the tax is manifestly unfair.

Speaker: margaret
Dialogue: Nonsense. Arrant nonsense. This is a simple proposition. In order to live in this country, you must pay for the privilege- something, anything! If you pay nothing, you care nothing. What do you care where you throw your rubbish? Your council estate is a mess, your town, graffiti, what do you care? It's not your problem , it's somebody else's problem- it's the government's problem! YOUR problem is, some of you, is that you haven't got the courage for this fight. You haven't had to fight hard for anything. It's all been given to you- and you feel guilty about it! Well, may I say, on behalf of all those who HAVE had to fight their way up,  we resent those slackers who take, take, take, and contribute nothing to the community!
MARGARET  And why have we not made more progress to date? What is that? Is that the timetable? I haven't seen that. May I see it?

Speaker: howe
Dialogue: Here it is, Prime Minister. Of course.

Speaker: margaret
Dialogue: The wording is sloppy here, and here.

Speaker: howe
Dialogue: If you say so.

Speaker: margaret
Dialogue: I do say so.

Speaker: howe
Dialogue: It's merely a first draft...

Speaker: margaret
Dialogue: This is ridiculous. There are two "T's" in "committee"!
MARGARET  As the Lord President has come to cabinet unprepared, I am obliged to close this meeting.

Speaker: angry crowd
Dialogue: Can't pay, won't pay! Can't pay, won't pay! Can't pay, won't pay!

Speaker: protestors
Dialogue: Out... Out... Out...

Speaker: protestors
Dialogue: Maggie... Maggie... Maggie. Out... out... out. With a WHOOSH of flames the north side of Piccadilly Circus goes up in flames. Smoke and blood and fire everywhere.

Speaker: margaret
Dialogue: Geoffrey- GEOFFREY My letter of resignation. HOWE slides a letter down on her desk- MARGARET looks down at the thick envelope. SILENCE

Dialogue: Our differences, I'm afraid, cannot be reconciled. MARGARET resumes working- HOWE waits and waits and waits- The SCRATCH of MARGARET's pen, she works on, refusing to stop for him.

Speaker: howe
Dialogue: I have done what I believe to be right for my party and my country. The time has come for others to consider their own response to the tragic conflict of loyalties with which I have myself wrestled for perhaps too long.

Speaker: tv journalist
Dialogue: It's extraordinary. The rules of the Conservative Party make it possible for Conservative MP's to depose a sitting Prime Minister.

Speaker: margaret
Dialogue: I am the Prime Minister.

Dialogue: Tonight in Paris Mrs Thatcher is among thirty four world leaders who came together to celebrate the end of the Cold War and herald the start of a peaceful new age of East/West cooperation.

Speaker: news journalist
Dialogue: There's a general feeling that Mrs Thatcher is going to win on the first ballot. We're going to put it to bed tomorrow night, is how one of her campaign staff puts it.

Speaker: trevor macdonald
Dialogue: Will she, or will she not, be in the job tomorrow?

Speaker: margaret
Dialogue: Treachery!

Speaker: minister 1
Dialogue: We will never win another election led by that woman.

Speaker: minister 2
Dialogue: We need a leader who listens.

Speaker: minister 3
Dialogue: This isn't about her, it's about the party.

Speaker: minister 4
Dialogue: One must know when to go.

Speaker: minister 1
Dialogue: The question is, how does anyone put it to her?

Speaker: minister
Dialogue: If you were to stand, I of course would vote for you Prime Minister -

Speaker: minister 2
Dialogue: - of course would vote for you Prime Minister but I don't think you can win. The loyalty of my colleagues cannot be counted upon.

Speaker: margaret
Dialogue: It was the people who put me here -

Speaker: minister 3
Dialogue: The loyalty of my colleagues cannot be counted upon.

Speaker: margaret
Dialogue: - it's up to them to tell me when to go.

Speaker: margaret
Dialogue: -proud to have left Britain in a much better state than when we took office.

Speaker: denis
Dialogue: Steady, MT.

Dialogue: All those years of taking the tough decisions, does any of it matter now?

Speaker: denis
Dialogue: It's all been turned to mush!

Speaker: margaret
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: denis
Dialogue: By these fools! These lily-livered pinkos!

Speaker: margaret
Dialogue: These inept placators.

Speaker: denis
Dialogue: Very good! These vacillators.

Speaker: margaret
Dialogue: Vacillators! Poll takers.

Speaker: denis
Dialogue: Popularity seekers.

Dialogue: So busy taking the pulse of the public!

Speaker: denis
Dialogue: Weak -

Speaker: margaret
Dialogue: These...weak...weak...weak...wea.. .weak...Men!

Dialogue: Or forget you entirely and chuck you out with the rubbish!

Dialogue: And you did, love, you did.

Speaker: margaret
Dialogue: Denis? Denis?

Dialogue: Denis wait...Where are your shoes? You can't go without shoes! Not yet.

Speaker: denis
Dialogue: Steady.

Dialogue: Yes...Steady...

Speaker: denis
Dialogue: Steady the buffs -

Speaker: margaret
Dialogue: Steady...Steady the buffs...

Speaker: denis
Dialogue: You're going to be fine on your own, love.  Denis!!

Dialogue: Mummy- CAROL looming over Margaret, looking horrified. CAROL My God, Mum. Are you alright?  Mummy you should have called for help, silly old sausage. Have you not even been in your bed properly? You've done all this? MARGARET Yes, all sorted. Finished. MARGARET looks around her.

Speaker: carol
Dialogue: Yes well don't worry about all this. June and I will crack on with it. MARGARET I was just going to get dressed.

Speaker: carol
Dialogue: ...Shall I call someone, see if anyone can come over and do your hair? MARGARET looks at her warmly. MARGARET Oh. No, you do it.

Dialogue: Right, I'm off June.

Dialogue: OK. `Bye. She stands, picking up the cup. From behind- JUNE  Oh let me do that, Margaret. MARGARET's turns for a moment- It is JUNE. MARGARET shakes her head. MARGARET No, dear, I'll do it. JUNE Carol said you might go to the House of Lords today? MARGARET No no. I'm not going anywhere.
